thread.title: One in four Brits admit to exaggerating their whereabouts on social media

author: Katie Amey for MailOnline
title: One in four Brits admit to exaggerating their whereabouts on social media
text:
15 shares 7
View
comments
Would you ever check in at a luxury location on social media... even if you've never actually been there?
According to a new survey, 'fauxbooking' is on the rise.
In fact, one in four Brits has admitted to exaggerating their whereabouts at one time or another on social media in a bid to imitate a more aspirational lifestyle.
According to a new study, 'fauxbooking,' where users check in to a luxury location they've never visited, is on the rise
The poll, conducted by No1 Lounges, found that luxury hotels and upmarket restaurants are the most popular locations to be exaggerated on social media, followed closely by exclusive nightclubs and VIP airport lounges.
Of the 26 per cent who admit to the 'faux check-ins', over half confess to exaggerating their whereabouts on a weekly basis.

Trail of destruction: The world heritage tourist sites wiped... 15 shares A further 20 per cent admitted to doing so at least once a month.
But their deceptive claims are relatively harmless, and sometimes, the lies are simply crafted in hopes of boosting their own self-esteem.
Luxury hotels, restaurants and clubs are the most popular locations to exaggerate on social media
The main motivation for doing so is to impress friends, while 29 per cent admit to fibbing in a bid to make themselves feel better.
But it seems those friends might be onto the fauxbookers among us, with 35 per cent admitting they have suspected a friend of exaggerating their true location at some point.
The biggest giveaway seems to be a lack of picture to accompany a post or the time of day the post is made.
The study also found that those aged 18-24 were the biggest social airbrushers, while those over the age of 55 were least likely to embellish their true location.
And it also appears that men more frequently exaggerate.
Those polled reveal that they often check in to fake places in order to impress friends or boost self-esteem
Phil Cameron, Founder & CEO of UK based No1 Lounges said: 'We've been amazed by the fauxbooking phenomenon but it's no surprise to see people wanting a slice of the jet set lifestyle.
The study revealed that almost half believed access to a VIP airport lounge would cost in excess of £50 when in reality it's more like £25.
'Fortunately we've made it possible for everyone to use these facilities, regardless of their airline or class of travel, making pre-flight luxury with a big price tag a thing of the past.'
